awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Computational Methods for Complex Fluids: Adaptivity, Fluid-Structure Interaction, and Applications in Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
Many biological systems involve flexible structures immersed in viscoelastic fluids (e.g., sperm in the reproductive tract, bacteria in the gut and lung, ciliary transport of mucus in the lung). In some cases, such as cilia-driven transport in the lung, these structures operate in a multi-fluid environment. Despite decades of work explicit challenges remain with developing suitable computational tools for the modeling of the complex fluid-structure interactions. The goal of this project is to develop and analyze accurate computational methods for these simulations, and to establish high-performance open-source implementations of these tools to be used by other researchers.  The new computational tools together with experimental measurements will be used to generate new insight into the mechanical behavior of mucus. Mucus provides a protective barrier for every human organ, and many diseases and disorders are associated with mucus pathology (e.g., in the lung (COPD, cystic fibrosis, asthma), stomach (ulcers), reproductive tract (infertility)). Moreover, tools developed as part of these projects have applications beyond mucus: to the food industry, for personal care products, as well as pharmaceutical applications, including drugs and drug delivery systems. The project will also provide broad interdisciplinary training for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in the mathematical sciences.

The specific research objectives of this project are 1) to develop and analyze efficient higher-order accurate numerical methods for fluid-structure interaction and fluid-fluid interaction problems involving complex fluids, 2) to validate these methods by comparison to experimental data of project collaborators, and 3) to develop mathematical models of industrial and biological systems, including microbead rheology, ciliar synchronization and transport, and phase separation of suspensions. Previous research on numerical methods for viscoelastic fluids has been driven by engineering applications, while biological applications pose new challenges: large deformations of active soft structures and complex rheology. Despite past efforts to understand the dynamics of active structures in complex fluids, a significant bottleneck persists: the lack of accurate, efficient, adaptive numerical methods and software for viscoelasstic fluid-structure interaction and fluid-fluid interfaces. The research team aims to build, validate, and apply this technology, guided by applications and experimental data from biology and engineering.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: FOCUSED RESEARCH GROUPS IN MATH SCIENCES

por.por_cntn:
This focused research group developed, analyzed, and applied mathematical methods for simulating and rheologically characterizing biological fluids, like respiratory mucus, and for simulating the interaction of biological fluids and immersed structures, such as swimming bacteria and cilia propulsion of mucus. Biological fluids like mucus are examples of complex or polymeric fluids and have properties that are very different from familiar Newtonian fluids, such as water. Further, polymeric fluids present challenges to many of the simulation methods that have previously been developed to enable computer models of fluid flows. Most previous research on numerical methods for simulating complex fluids has been motivated by engineering applications rather than biological models. Biological applications can pose different challenges because they often involve transient, weak interactions within and between the polymer molecules as well as large deformations of dynamic active or passive soft structures in the fluid. A general numerical difficulty arises from the need to resolve highly localized stresses that develop in elastic fluids under high strain, which concentrate preferentially near immersed structures, including active structures such as bacteria, cilia, and sperm. Another numerical difficulty arises to understand how weak, transient interactions act on the large polymers to tune the structure and rheology of complex fluids like mucus. Yet another numerical and statistical difficulty is the ability to extract the signal from the noise in passive microbead rheology when the beads reside within dense domains and therefore have very low mobility. Despite intense efforts by diverse modeling communities to understand the dynamics of active structures in complex fluids and the activation by weak, transient interactions of the complex fluid itself over the past decade, this work has been impeded by a significant bottleneck: the lack of accurate, robust numerical methods and software for viscoelastic fluid-structure interactions, including both active and passive structures. This project worked to remove these bottlenecks. Specific outcomes include new high-resolution adaptive numerical methods for complex fluid simulation, which allow for the deployment of high spatial resolution near flow features that have localized fine-scale structure, high-resolution methods for simulating biological fluid flows around immersed structures that are capable of resolving both flow and stress dynamics, physics and chemistry informed molecular dynamic simulations of chemically activated complex fluids, new maximum likelihood classifiers of particle-tracking data in the presence of high noise-to-signal, and applications of these methods to understand experimental data obtained from microbead rheology experiments on biological complex fluids such as mucus. Many of the core methods developed in this project have been released to the scientific community and the broader public through the open-source IBAMR software (https://ibamr.github.io). The project also directly supported graduate student training in applied mathematics and computational science, leading to two completed PhDs at UNC-Chapel Hill and a third that is in progress. The project also directly supported training of a postdoctoral fellow, who successfully transitioned to a staff position at a Department of Energy national laboratory. Additional students and postdoctoral researchers interacted with the project but were not directly supported.


Last Modified: 01/12/2023
Modified by: Boyce E Griffith
